This is the case of a 63 year old black male who was a resident at Gregory Community Center, a residential facility for adults with mental disabilities.  His cause of death was terminal pancreatic cancer.  The manner of death is natural.
We are trying to locate next of kin.

On July 3, 2008 the Charleston County Coronerâ€™s Office was notified by the Charleston County Sheriffâ€™s Office about a tip they received from a criminal informant of a possible murder.  Reportedly the victim, Ala Sarhan, was placed in the trunk of his vehicle and pushed off the Wambaw boat landing into the water in McClellanville.  

Charleston County divers located a vehicle submerged in the water with NC license tag.  The tag was registered to a 1991 two door Chevrolet Lumina registered to Ala Hassan Sarhan.  The Sheriffâ€™s Office obtained a search warrant and located skeletal remains in the trunk of the vehicle.  Ala Hassan Sarhan had been reported missing by his girlfriend to the Sheriffâ€™s Office on 07/19/2000, at which time she stated that the last time she saw or heard from him was on 07/12/2000. He was driving his 1991 Chevrolet Lumina.  He was described as of Middle Eastern descent, having a left foot prosthesis/brace.     

The Coronerâ€™s office performed an extensive search to locate the decedentâ€™s next-of-kin, however, they were unsuccessful.  Throughout our investigation we learned that the decedent was a refugee from Iraq who arrived in the USA in 1992.  We were unable to locate the decedentâ€™s dental records, but located medical records that documented his left foot injury; we also spoke to previous employers who confirmed the foot injury.  

The cause of death was determined to be homicidal violence.  The manner is â€œHomicideâ€.

physicalFeatureDescriptions.description: traumatic amputation of lower left distal extremity

On September 6, 2007 The Charleston County Coronerâ€™s Office was notified by the Charleston City Police Department on the death of a homeless man at Ansonborough Field.

I responded to the incident location and met with city officers who reported that the decedent was last seen alive by a friend who spoke to him at approximately 0830 hours.  According to the friend the decedent was in the same location then and when he spoke to him the decedent asked him to leave him alone.  A worker from the port noticed the decedent in the same location midday and at 1730 hours when he observed that he was still there he called the police.  Police responded along with EMS who pronounced him dead.  

The officers were familiar with the decedent and identified him as 64 year old Edward Francis Dwyer. His identity was also confirmed by fingerprints. I examined the body and found no signs of injury or trauma.  He was wearing a dark gray polo shirt, gray shorts, white socks, black shoes and a gray hat.  

After photographs of the scene and body were completed the body was transported by Carolina Funeral Service to MUSC until family could be located.  

Medical records were obtained which showed the decedent had an extensive medical history.
   
The decedent had been homeless for years.  Attempts were made to find the next of kin but to no avail.  This office received authorization from probate court to have his body cremated.
The body was released to Palmetto Cremation Society.  Buried at Beaufort National Cemetery, section C3, grave 145.

On April 26, 2009 the Charleston County Coronerâ€™s Office was notified by the emergency room at East Cooper Hospital of the probable natural death of George Main, a 59 year old white male.

I responded to the emergency room.  Medical personnel reported that the decedent was transported by EMS from the parking lot of Pier One Imports.  Reportedly, the decedent locked his keys in his car at Pier One Imports and walked back to his apartment.  He obtained his spare keys and his roommate drove him back to his car.  While in the car the decedent became short of breath and then unresponsive.  EMS responded and resuscitative attempts were attempted to no avail.  

I spoke with the decedentâ€™s roommate and lifelong friend.  He reported that the decedent had a previous history of heart disease but had not been to a doctor in several years.  He also reported that the two of them were missionaries overseas for several years and he was not aware of any family.  

The Charleston County Coronerâ€™s Office performed an extensive search for next-of-kin but had negative results.  Our office sought authorization for cremation by the Probate Court and it was granted.  The decedentâ€™s body was released to Palmetto Cremation Society.

clothingAndAccessoriesArticles.description: wallet, 2 rings (given to roommate by order of nursing supervisor)

On Friday March 17, 2006 at 12:37 pm I received a call from a No. Trident Hospital nursing supervisor who reported that Clayton Meeks was a 68 year old white male who was brought to the emergency room by EMS from White Oak Manor nursing facility where he was found unresponsive. He was pronounced dead shortly after his arrival at the hospital. There is a known, detailed medical history. I was also told Mr. Meeks appeared to be well cared for and the death appeared to be from natural causes.  Buried at the Beaufort National Cemetery, Section C3, grave 150.
